clinical_study.brief_title: Development of a Mobile Application to Promote Self-care in Patients With Fibromyalgia
clinical_study.official_title: Development of a Mobile Application to Promote Self-care in Patients With Fibromyalgia

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Sao Paulo General Hospital

collaborator.agency: Fundação de Amparo à Pesquisa do Estado de São Paulo

clinical_study.source: University of Sao Paulo General Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to test the efficacy of a mobile application named ProFibro to promote self-care, and improve symptoms and health-related quality of life in Brazilian patients with fibromyalgia.

primary_outcome.measure: Health-related quality of life assessed with the Revised Fibromyalgia Impact Questionnaire

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain assessed with the Widespread Pain Index
Pain assessed with the Visual Analogue Scale
Severity of symptoms assessed with the Symptom Severity Scale
Self-care agency assessed with the Appraisal of Self-Care Agency Scale - Revised
secondary_outcome.description: Appraisal of Self-Care Agency Scale - Revised

secondary_outcome.measure: Adherence to mobile application assessed by number of clicks on the app functions
secondary_outcome.description: Number of clicks on the app functions

intervention.description: ProFibro, a mobile Android application in Brazilian Portuguese to promote self-care in patients with fibromyalgia
A 64-page booklet with content similar to the mobile application

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- diagnosis of fibromyalgia, according to the 2010 American College of Rheumatology diagnostic criteria
- smartphone user
- complete primary education
Exclusion Criteria:
- being in physical therapy treatment for fibromyalgia or having been treated in the last 3 months
- diagnosis of other chronic pain conditions (neuropathies, rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, spinal stenosis or cancer)
- severe mental disorders (schizophrenia, psychosis, bipolar affective disorder, severe depression)
- moderate or severe intellectual disability
- hearing or visual impairment
